title: New York City police recruits to watch a play for training
text:
John Minchillo New York City police recruits to watch a play for training 
FILE - In this Dec. 29, 2014 file photo, NYPD police commissioner Bill Bratton stands on stage during a New York Police Academy graduation ceremony in New York. The city’s Police Academy has added the one-act play “Anne & Emmett” by Janet Langhart Cohen to its recruit training this fall. The play is an imaginary conversation between Anne Frank, who died in a Nazi concentration camp, and Emmett Till, who was killed by a racist mob in Mississippi in 1955. The play will be performed for some 1,100 recruits at their academy in Queens over two performances on Thursday, part of a push by the department to prepare future police officers to overcome community mistrust and their own bias. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File) Posted: Friday, October 16, 2015 3:08 pm | Updated: 3:45 pm, Fri Oct 16, 2015. New York City police recruits to watch a play for training Associated Press | 
NEW YORK (AP) — The New York City Police Department is turning to a new tool in its effort to teach its future officers about tolerance and understanding — drama. 
The city's Police Academy has added the one-act play "Anne & Emmett" by Janet Langhart Cohen to its diversity training. The play is an imaginary conversation between Anne Frank, who died in a Nazi concentration camp, and Emmett Till, who was killed by racists in Mississippi in 1955. 
The play will be performed for some 1,100 recruits in Queens over two performances on Thursday, part of a push by the department to address community mistrust. 
Says the playwright: "If the play can reach one man or woman with a badge and a gun, I'm happy."
